Article: The Pentagonâs top research agency is taking a no-nonsense approach toadvancing development of a fundamental component of AI technology known as âmachine common sense.â The Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA), which announced a multi-year $2 billion âAI Nextâ campaign in September, is tightening its focus on developing machine âcommon senseâ reasoning. The basic research effort includes two technology tracks, the first focusing on fundamentals, or âlearning like a child.â   The second includes developing models based on deep learning and other approaches to develop frameworks that can solve problems based on current AI industry benchmarks. The effort also provides momentum for academic research in this esoteric but vital area of cognitive studies that dates to the 1960s.Â  The DARPA program starts with the premise the machines lack basic knowledge about the physical world that all humans possess. Expressing and encoding that capability has so far confounded AI researchers who tend to focus on either narrow or general AI problems. Those models are considered âbrittle,â falling well short of human cognition. âItâs new territory [and] it turns out to be incredibly difficult,â said David Gunning, a program manager in DARPAâs Information Innovation Office. âEvery [human] action is on top of this iceberg of common-sense knowledge.â Even a one-year-old child âhas an incredible understanding of the physical worldâ that machines canât come close to matching, Gunning said. If the basic research program pans out, DARPA hopes to use the resulting models to develop new machine learning applications. âWeâll get something started that will synergizeâ further industry development, Gunning added in an interview.Â  Potential common sense âservicesâ include models that learn from experience as might a child learning spatial navigation. Another would mimic a research librarian browsing the web to gather facts that could be used to provide common-sense answers to natural language or image-based questions about the physical world. One potential application dubbed âsensemakingâ would augment AI systems that analyze sensor data. A machine common sense model could then help interpret and understand real-world scenarios. Another described by Gunning is a âsimulated common sense agent [operating] in a 3-D simulated environment.â Gunningâs office kicked the effort with a recent âProposers’ Dayâ designed to brief potential bidders on program requirements. The agency said it would fund research exploring developmental psychology, then establish a set of cognitive development milestones for determining how the resulting computational models learn in three areas: experience learning, prediction and âexpectation,â as well as problem solving.Â  A parallel effort will use web browsing to assemble a repository of machine common sense capable of answering queries based on natural language and images. The resulting âbroad common knowledgeâ that would mimic general adult knowledge will be tested against the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence benchmarks. Those metrics cover common sense understanding of natural language, machine vision and a form of inference known as abductive reasoning that seeks, for example, to infer intent. Participants in the DARPA program will be given test problems for which they must build a machine to answer a series of questions. Gunning said developers could use deep learning models, crowdsourcing techniques and other novel approaches to come up with a machine common sense framework that could help fill the current gap between narrow and general AI. Machine common sense and other DARPA efforts are part of its more than $2 billion portfolio of AI research programs aimed at advancing beyond current technologies that require large amounts of training data. Those approaches often fail to adapt to change and are unable to provide users with explanations of their results. As the global AI race heats up, with China and European countries announcing aggressive development roadmaps, the DARPA AI Next effort serves a de facto U.S. strategy. Google and others are pouring billions into AI research, and DARPA wants to augment those efforts with high-risk, high-payoff research into areas like machine common sense that may not deliver immediate commercial applications. âWe want to explore how machines can acquire human-like communication and reasoning capabilities, with the ability to recognize new situations and environments and adapt to them,â DARPA director Steven Walker said in unveiling the umbrella AI effort. âMachines lack contextual reasoning capabilities, and their training must cover every eventuality, which is not only costly, but ultimately impossible.
